Chapter 8, part 3 on the three kinds of samÄdhi, having explained the meditative attainments.
What are the samÄdhis?

The sÅ«tras generally speak of three kinds of samÄdhis: 1. samÄdhi with initial and sustained thought, 2. samÄdhi without initial thought but only sustained thought, 3. samÄdhi without initial or sustained thought.
What are the distinguishing characteristics of these three?
Verse:
The first has initial and sustained thought, the middle has only sustained thought, the upper has neither.
Treatise:

Previously, for the sake of the matter, these three were repeatedly discussed. Now, in this [chapter], the distinguishing characteristics are briefly revealed.ğŸ”½SamÄdhi with initial and sustained thought refers to samÄdhi associated with initial and sustained thought. This is included in the first dhyÄna and the preliminary stage.
SamÄdhi without initial thought but only sustained thought refers to samÄdhi associated only with sustained thought. This is included in the intermediate dhyÄna stage.

SamÄdhi without applied thought and sustained thought is samÄdhi not associated with applied thought and sustained thought. It is included in the stage of access to the second dhyÄna and above, up to the sphere of neither-perception-nor-non-perception.
The scriptures also speak of three kinds of samÄdhi: 1. the samÄdhi of emptiness, 2. the samÄdhi of wishlessness, and 3. the samÄdhi of signlessness.
What are the specific characteristics of these three?
Verse:
Emptiness refers to emptiness and non-self, signlessness refers to the cessation of the four,
Wishlessness refers to the remaining ten, corresponding to the aspects of the truths;
These are both pure and uncontaminated, and the uncontaminated ones are the three gates of liberation.
Treatise:

The samÄdhi of emptiness is samÄdhi associated with the two aspects of emptiness and non-self. Therefore, it is said that the samÄdhi of emptiness is the proximate antidote to the view of a real self, because the view of a real self also has two aspects.

The aspect of emptiness is a proximate antidote to the view of mine, and the aspect of nonself is a proximate antidote to the view of self. The contemplation that dharmas are not a self is called the aspect of nonself. The contemplation that there is no self in them is called the aspect of emptiness.
Consequently, the aspect of emptiness is a proximate antidote to the view of mine, because there is absolutely no self in this. Therefore, these dharmas are not mine.
Isnâ€™t the aspect of emptiness the aspect of nonself? What difference is there between the two aspects of knowing that this is not a self and that there is no self in this?
There is a difference, because the words there is no self in this do not reveal that the self is absolutely nonexistent.
This only reveals that this and that are mutually absent, but it does not reveal that the self is absolutely nonexistent, because dharmas that exist do not exist in each other.
If it is said that this dharma is not a self, then it reveals that the self is absolutely nonexistent, because all dharmas are equal in their characteristics.
Consequently, if one cultivates the aspect of nonself, one then remedies the view of self. If one cultivates the aspect of emptiness, one remedies the view of mine. How can there be no difference?
Concentration associated with the four aspects of the truth of cessation is called concentration of signlessness, because nirvana is devoid of signs.
There are ten kinds of signs: the five such as form, the two sexes, and the three marks of the conditioned.
Or, signs are another name for causes, and nirvana has no causes, so it is called signless.
Or, signs are the superior, middling, and inferior of the world, and nirvana is different from them, so it is called signless.
Concentration associated with the ten aspects of the other truths is called concentration of wishlessness.
The ten aspects are suffering, impermanence, cause, accumulation, birth, condition, path, suchness, practice, and exit.

Although the characteristics of these three concentrations such as emptiness are not different, they are established in three kinds according to their antidotes, intentions, and objects, in that order.
It is reasonable to say that one does not seek the three realms of existence because they are full of suffering,
but how can one not seek the holy path because of ones attitude?
Because the holy path is related to existence.
If this is so, then why cultivate the holy path?
Because it is the cause that leads to nirvana.
There is no attainment of nirvana apart from the holy path, and one cultivates the holy path in order to seek nirvana.

The path is like a boat or a raft and one must abandon it. Also, because of ones attitude, one does not seek the holy path. Therefore the aspects of the path are also called wishless, because one originally made a vow to detest conditioned dharmas.

The aspects of emptiness and nonself are not to be abandoned, because they are similar to nirvana. Consequently, even though these two aspects of the truths of suffering and the origin have aspects that are to be detested, they do not take on the aspect of being detestable and are not called wishless.
These three samadhis are categorized as pure and uncontaminated, because they are included in the supramundane and mundane samadhis.

Because it is included in the mundane realm, it is found in eleven stages. If it is included in the supramundane realm, it is found only in nine stages, because the upper seven trance states lack superior qualities.
Among these, the pure ones are called the three gates of liberation, because they can serve as gates of entry into nirvana.
Not all impure dharmas are true gates of liberation, because their natures abide in the mundane realm and oppose liberation.
As for the specific objects of the three samadhis, if they are impure, emptiness takes all dharmas as objects. If they are pure, emptiness takes only the truth of suffering as its object.
Non-desire is able to take the truths of suffering, accumulation, and the path as objects. The signless only takes the truth of cessation as its object.
As for the specific foundations of mindfulness of the three samadhis, the signless is only the dharma foundation, while the others are all four.
The sutras also speak of three kinds of samadhis: the samadhi of emptiness of emptiness, the samadhi of non-desire of non-desire, and the samadhi of signlessness of signlessness.
What are the specific characteristics of these three?
Verse:
The two subsequent ones take emptiness and impermanence as their aspects, respectively.
The subsequent one takes the formless concentration of signlessness as its object and takes non-analytical cessation as its aspect of quiescence.
The impure one is not bound to time and is free from the seven proximate formless concentrations.
The treatise says:
These three samÄdhis take the emptiness, etc., of previous emptiness, etc., as their objects and take emptiness, etc., as their aspects. Therefore they are called emptiness of emptiness, etc.

The samÄdhi of emptiness of emptiness takes the previous Å›aiká¹£a emptiness samÄdhi as its object and takes its aspect of emptiness. The aspect of emptiness is in accord with disgust and is superior to the aspect of non-self.

This means that one first gives rise to a Å›aiká¹£a samÄdhi and contemplates the aspect of emptiness regarding the five appropriated aggregates. After this, one gives rise to a samÄdhi associated with a superior wholesome root and takes the previous Å›aiká¹£a emptiness samÄdhi as its object, contemplating its aspect of emptiness. Because one takes emptiness as emptiness, it is called emptiness of emptiness.
It is like burning a corpse with a stick, and when the corpse is exhausted, the stick should also be burned.
In the same way, after emptiness burns afflictions, one again gives rise to emptiness concentration to disgust and abandon the previous emptiness. The samÄdhi of emptiness of emptiness is like this.
When the aspect of emptiness arises, it is immediately followed by the aspect of emptiness, because this is the most skillful in causing one to turn away from and abandon the aggregates.
The aspect of nonself is not like this, because one who sees nonself in conditioned dharmas generates a mind that turns away from them, but not as much as when one sees emptiness.
Those who have already seen that dharmas are without self still generate pleasure in regard to the three realms of existence because they have not thoroughly seen emptiness in the aggregates.

Consequently, although the two aspects of emptiness and nonself both occur in the samÄdhi of emptiness, it is only called emptiness and not nonself, because emptiness is most conducive to turning away from and abandoning the aggregates.
The samÄdhi of wishlessness in regard to wishlessness takes the aspect of impermanence as its object, that is, the prior wishlessness of the post-learner.

That is, one first generates the samÄdhi of a post-learner and reflects on the aspect of impermanence in regard to the five aggregates that are grasped. Subsequently, one generates a samÄdhi associated with a superior wholesome root and takes as its object the prior wishless samÄdhi of the post-learner, reflecting on the aspect of impermanence. One does not wish for wishlessness, and this is called the samÄdhi of wishlessness in regard to wishlessness.
The analogy is to be understood as above.

The heavy samÄdhi of non-desire, etc., after arising with the aspect of impermanence, immediately returns to being associated with the aspect of impermanence. Only this can take the path of disgust as its object.
The aspect of suffering cannot take the noble path as its object, because the noble path is not suffering, because it leads to the cessation of suffering.

Suffering dharmas cannot lead to the cessation and extinction of suffering, nor can the four such as cause, etc., take the noble path as their object, because the noble path cannot cause suffering to continue.
The four such as path, etc., are not the four such as cause, etc., because this disgust and abandonment of the path is not the aspect of joy that can cause disgust and abandonment.

Isn't it like the non-desire that does not desire the noble path, but makes the four such as path, etc.? This should also be so.ğŸ”½This example is not correct. Non-desire correctly disgusts existence, and because it gives rise to a mind of non-desire regarding the noble path, it is able to take the noble path as its object.
That is to say, the previous non-desire correctly disgusts existence, and because the noble path relies on existence, it also gives rise to a mind of non-desire.
Although it is said that the intention does not wish for the path, still it does not truly detest the noble path, and therefore it can also make the four kinds of path, etc.
The non-wish for the non-wish truly detests the path, and therefore it views the path as a fault by means of the contemplation of impermanence.
The aspects of the path, etc., cannot detest the path, and therefore it does not make those four kinds in regard to it.
If the path can be detested because it is impermanent, then one should make the aspect of the activity of suffering in regard to the noble path, because it has that aspect.
As a scripture says:
All that is impermanent is suffering.
The noble path cannot have the aspect of suffering, because it is established as a truth, and the aspects are different.
That is, the name truth of suffering is established in reliance upon a different aspect. How can the noble path also have the aspect of suffering?
Also, because a scripture makes a distinction, as a scripture says:
In brief, all five aggregates of the present are suffering.
If the path has the aspect of suffering because it is impermanent, then it should be said to be only the aggregates.
Since it is said that only the aggregates that are grasped are included in suffering, this proves that the holy path is not suffering.

If you say that, just as one contemplates the cause of suffering and it is suffering, although the characteristics of the truths are different, the view is not an error, because the five aggregates that are grasped are both suffering and its cause,

then you should understand that one contemplates the path and it is suffering, and although the characteristics of the truths are different, the view is not an error, because the pure aggregates are both suffering and the path. Consequently, the principle of the establishment of the truths is not destroyed.

This is also unreasonable. It is definitely not the case that one contemplates the cause of suffering and it is suffering, and the view is not an error, because the five aggregates that are grasped are called the cause of suffering and are called suffering, and their natures are different.
If one contemplates the cause as the effect, then one must contemplate the effect as the cause, because the different causes and conditions cannot be found.
This is an erroneous view and is not included in the contemplation of the truths. How can it be said that the principle of the establishment of the truths is not destroyed?

In that case, there would be no difference between the knowledge of suffering and the knowledge of the cause of suffering, or else the knowledge of suffering and the knowledge of the path would be like the knowledge of the cause of suffering, because their objects would not be different, and consequently they would be established together as the overlord of the truths.

That is, since they say that suffering and its cause are the same in substance, to contemplate the cause as suffering is not a perverted view, because the objects of the two knowledges are the same, and therefore the two are not established as distinct forms of complete knowledge.

In the same way, it should be said that suffering and the path are the same in substance, and to contemplate the path as suffering is not a perverted view, because the objects of the two knowledges are the same, and therefore the two are not established as distinct forms of complete knowledge.
Since this is not admitted, how can the path be suffering?
Also, the path and suffering are different in substance, because a scripture says,
The five pure faculties cut off all suffering of the past, future, and present.
Also, it is said that the path cuts off suffering, which has birth as its basis.
Also, a scripture says,
The path should be cultivated, and suffering should be eternally eliminated.
Therefore the path is not suffering.
If you say that a scripture says that the Dharma is like a raft and should be eliminated, this is also unreasonable, because the scripture does not say that the Dharma is eliminated by its antidote.

That is, the path of the saints is cultivated in the past, and when its function is completed, it is no longer cultivated. It is said to be abandoned in the sense of being discarded, and it is not eliminated by the antidote, because it is not the same as suffering.
Or, in the scriptures, the word dharma refers to the teachings of the scriptures, etc. The word â€œshould be abandonedâ€ shows that one should forget the explanation and grasp the meaning.

Or, the scriptures say that even the dharma should be abandoned. This shows that a cause that has already produced its effect can be abandoned, just as the stage of abiding can be abandoned. It is not like the nature of suffering, which the path can also abandon.
Therefore, suffering and the path are different in substance.

Moreover, if the scriptures say that all that is impermanent is suffering, and that the holy path also has the characteristic of suffering, and the scriptures also say that all that is suffering is not self, then you should hold that nirvana is not the nature of non-self, or you should also admit that it is suffering and impermanent. If you admit this, then it must definitely not be the nature of nirvana.

If you say that the words all that is suffering is not self do not mean that all that is not self is suffering, why do you not also say that the words all that is suffering is impermanent do not mean that all that is impermanent is suffering?

If you say that the substance of impermanence is suffering and suffering is not self, and that the words are merely different, then emptiness and wishlessness would have no differences, because you admit that not self is the same as suffering, etc.

If you say that the scripture says that suffering is not self, and you admit that all suffering is not of the nature of self, then since this scripture says that the impermanent is suffering, you must admit that all that is impermanent is of the nature of suffering.
This is really so, because this scripture does not speak of the path in the words that it uses for impermanence.
On the basis of what principle does it speak of impermanence?

Because the foolish and the worldling cling to the five aggregates of material elements and impute permanence to them, etc., and give rise to the four errors. In order to destroy this clinging, it speaks the words of impermanence.

The text continues, â€œWhat is impermanent is suffering,â€ which means that all conditioned states that are impermanent are suffering by nature, and all suffering is not self. It does not mean that all impermanent things are suffering.
This must be the correct interpretation, because the scripture says that impermanence is a characteristic of the realm of suffering.
Or, when the scripture says â€œimpermanence,â€ it does not refer only to that which is associated with birth and death, but also to that which is associated with death and rebirth.

That is, ignorant people consider the pleasures of humans and celestials to be happiness, and therefore the scripture says that they are suffering because they have a gross impermanence, just as the three evil destinies are.
What is the evidence that the scripture refers to impermanence, etc., only in terms of the conditioned?
Because the scripture later says,
â€œForm, sensation, etc., are not self, and therefore are impermanent.â€
Can nirvana also be said to be impermanent?
Therefore we know that this scripture refers only to the four aspects of the holy wisdom that has as its object the truth of suffering.
If you say that the holy path is suffering because it is impermanent, why not admit that the path is not suffering because it is pure?

If you say that the view that pleasure is suffering is eliminated by the path of insight into the truths of cessation and path, why do you say that it is eliminated by the path of insight into the truth of cessation? The error of regarding cessation as suffering is very grave.
This is because one who regards nirvÄá¹‡a as suffering increases the mind that delights in birth and death to the extreme.
The view of the path is not like this, and for that reason it is said in a one-sided way that it is eliminated by the path of insight into the truth of cessation.
It is easy to cure a patient who is disgusted with medicine, but if he is disgusted with the medicine that cures his illness, it is difficult to save him.

Or, because the holy paths turn on the basis of suffering, the error of regarding them as suffering is not very grave. For this reason, the ÅšÄstra says in brief that it is eliminated by the path of insight into the truth of cessation, but because it is said to exist in other places, there is no contradiction in meaning.
Also, a scripture says,
If one understands pleasure as it really is in joy and pleasure, I definitely say that he realizes the four truths as they really are.

Therefore we know that conditioned dharmas are not entirely suffering. Consequently, one can contemplate impermanence in the path and achieve the heavy aspiration for non-production, but one definitely does not contemplate suffering.
The signless of the signless takes as its object the non-analytical cessation that is the signless of the state of no learning, because there is no analytical cessation of pure dharmas.
But it only takes the mark of quiescence, not that of cessation, of wondrousness, or of separation.

That is, one first produces a concentration of the class of learners, and in this one reflects on the mark of quiescence in cessation through discrimination. After this, one produces a superior concentration associated with wholesome roots, and this has as its object the nondiscriminative cessation of nondiscriminative concentration of the class of learners. The metaphor is to be understood as above.

The concentration of nondiscriminativeness is followed by the mark of quiescence, and then one again becomes associated with the mark of quiescence, because only this can contemplate nondiscriminative cessation.
It is not the mark of wondrousness, because the object is indeterminate.
It is not the mark of separation, because although one realizes nondiscriminative cessation, one is still bound to it.
It is not the mark of cessation, because nondiscriminative cessation is not a permanent liberation from all suffering.
Also, if one contemplates cessation, it is confused with impermanence. Therefore, quiescence only manifests cessation, and thus nondiscriminative cessation has the mark of quiescence.

Because one cultivates the holy path for a long time with great effort, one gives rise to the notion of pleasure in that cessation. Therefore, one values the signless that takes tranquility as its object, not the others.

The three samÄdhis that value the three are only contaminated, because one abandons the holy path with disgust, not because one abandons the holy path with disgust through the uncontaminated samÄdhis.

This is the cause of not turning the wheel of the signless samÄdhi of the post-learner. Therefore, it is called the path of abandoning.
That is to say, when this samÄdhi arises, it means:
It is good that the signless samÄdhi does not arise.
Since this praises and delights in the non-arising of the holy path, how can it not be called abandoning the holy path with disgust?
The previous signless samÄdhi is not the object of this. How can this be called the signless of the signless?
Or it should be allowed that this samÄdhi does not take non-analytical cessation as its object, but only takes the non-arising of the signless of the post-learner as its object.
This is also unreasonable, because it is explained in the same way as before.
That is, the object of the concentration of signlessness is the nondiscriminative cessation of the realm of desire, and this nondiscriminative cessation is also free from all signs.
Because it is the object of the concentration of signlessness, it is given the name signlessness of signlessness.
It takes the aspect of calm in regard to the object of signlessness, and therefore this concentration is named from its object.
Only humans of the three continents can produce this concentration, and it is common to both men and women, because one can freely prolong or shorten life by relying on a female body.
It is only in the state of post-learner, because learners are only delighted with the holy path and are not yet disgusted with it.
It is also not all post-learners, but only those who are liberated regardless of occasion, because those liberated only through concentration are attached to the holy path.
It is based on eleven stages, excluding the upper seven formless stages, because the upper seven stages have no superior virtues.
If it is in the realm of desire, it arises after the holy path of the preliminary stage.
If it is in the peak of existence, it arises after the holy path of the sphere of nothingness.

A scripture teaches four kinds of samÄdhi cultivation: the samÄdhi cultivation for the enjoyment of present life, the samÄdhi cultivation for the attainment of superior knowledge and vision, the samÄdhi cultivation for the attainment of discernment wisdom, and the samÄdhi cultivation for the complete extinction of the contaminants.

A verse says:
Cultivating various wholesome meditations for the enjoyment of present life;
Cultivating the pure divine eye for the attainment of superior knowledge and vision;
Cultivating various preparatory wholesome dharmas for the attainment of discernment wisdom;

The treatise says:
As a scripture teaches, there is cultivation of samÄdhi that, if practiced, cultivated, and repeated, leads to the attainment of enjoyment of the present life, and so on at length.
The word wholesome includes both pure and uncontaminated.
One cultivates the good meditations and obtains the bliss of the present existence, but the scripture only speaks of the first meditation, because the thought of bliss is most abundant in it.
That is, one transcends the many faults of the realm of desire, and therefore the thought of bliss is most abundant in it.

Or, because it possesses the bliss of the holy path, that is, it possesses all the factors of enlightenment, the four fruits of the Å›ramaá¹‡a, the nine complete knowledges, and the antidotes of the three realms.

Thus, bhiká¹£us!

Examining this, it only speaks of the bliss of the present existence. In order to cause one to abandon the bliss of present desires, it speaks of the bliss of the present meditations and causes one to delight in them.

First abiding here, one enters various samÄdhis, and later one is born there.

Although the various dhyÄnas are present happiness, because they rely on the preliminary concentration, it is said that one attains them, because by the power of cultivating the preliminary concentration one attains the fundamental concentration.

Some say that this samÄdhi is spoken of by the Buddha himself, just as it is said that the bodhisattva dwells in the JÄmbÅ« forest, gives rise to the first worldly samÄdhi that resembles the undefiled samÄdhi, and is able to bring about the common happiness of all beings. For this reason, it does not speak of abiding in present happiness.
For this very reason, it only speaks of the first, because at that time the bodhisattva only attains the first.
If one cultivates the supernormal knowledge of the heavenly eye in dependence on the various meditative absorptions, one will then be able to acquire the superior knowledge and vision.
In what sense is this called knowledge and vision?

There is a knowledge of universal illumination in the fundamental meditative absorptions. Because it universally illuminates, it is called vision. Because the substance of vision is knowledge, it is called knowledge and vision.
The eye faculty is called vision, as is well known in the world. In order to distinguish it from that, it is called knowledge and vision.
Or, this vision is called knowledge because it determines its object, and it is also called vision.

That is to say, the fundamental meditative absorptions are the path of pleasant practice, because they are manifested without much exertion. Because there is no exertion, their substance is firm. Because their substance is firm, their function is certain. Because their function is certain, they are called knowledge.
Vision has the same meaning as before, and therefore it is called knowledge and vision.
Cultivating this meditative absorption in order to know and see is precisely in order to seek certain illumination. This is also what the Well-Gone One has said based on himself.

That is, in order to manifest that the Buddha, by means of the supernormal power of the heavenly eye, observes the perilous difficulties of the death and rebirth of all sentient beings, and then rescues them by producing the dhyanas, etc., he therefore cultivates the supernormal power of the heavenly eye in order to know and see.
Other masters say:

In order to subdue and conquer all secondary passions, he produces superior knowledge and vision. The production of this superior knowledge and vision is not apart from the thought of light. This thought of light attracts the supernormal power of the heavenly eye, and by means of the supernormal power of the heavenly eye, one obtains superior knowledge and vision.
If one cultivates the good of the three realms that is preparatory effort and the pure good, one obtains discriminating understanding.
That is, the good dharmas of hearing, thinking, and cultivation up to the summit of existence, and all other pure conditioned dharmas, are generally called the good dharmas of preparatory effort.

The cultivation of these good dharmas can attract the production of understanding, which evolves in regard to distinctions among objects. Therefore it is said that by cultivating them one obtains discriminating understanding.

It is said that the Well-Gone One, abiding in two kinds of investigation, can know in reality the arising of feelings, etc. This shows that by cultivating the good one obtains discriminating understanding.

Thus, the samÄdhi that is the basis has been explained. Next, we will explain the merits that arise based on samÄdhi.
Among the merits, we will first explain the immeasurables.
Verse:

Loving-kindness and compassion have the nature of non-hatred, joy is joy, and equanimity is non-greed.

The treatise says:
There are four immeasurables, namely loving-kindness, compassion, joy, and equanimity.
As for immeasurables, they take immeasurable sentient beings as objects. Because these four can attract immeasurable blessings, and because they are the causes of immeasurable loving results.
Some say:
Because they can oppose immeasurable discursive thoughts, and because greed and so forth are all called discursive thoughts.
Why are the immeasurables four and no more?
Because they counteract the four kinds of most frequently occurring obstructions.
As a sutra says:

If you practice, cultivate, and do much of loving-kindness, it can eliminate hatred. If you practice, cultivate, and do much of compassion, it can eliminate harm. If you practice, cultivate, and do much of sympathetic joy, it can eliminate dissatisfaction. If you practice, cultivate, and do much of equanimity, it can eliminate desire and hatred. Therefore, there are only four.
Hatred is a mental factor that wishes to kill sentient beings.
Harm is a mental factor that wishes to afflict sentient beings.
Dissatisfaction is the cause of not delighting in abiding in goodness, being attached to objects.
Desire and greed is the delight and pleasure arising from defiled attachment to wonderful desired objects, with no contentment.
Herein, loving-kindness and compassion have non-hatred as their nature.
If so, what is the difference between the two?

Although their natures are not different, loving-kindness eliminates the hatred that kills sentient beings and functions with the aspect of joy. Compassion eliminates the hatred that afflicts sentient beings and functions with the aspect of sorrow. This is the difference.
Just as suffering and pleasure are the same in being feelings, but benefit and harm are different, therefore their natures are different.
The natures of suffering and pleasure are different, as already explained.
The differences between the two of loving-kindness and compassion are also like this.
There is an opinion that
compassion is non-harming, because it is a proximate antidote to harming.
This is really so, but harming is similar to anger, and is called anger.
The mode of activity of compassion is also similar to non-anger, and is established as non-anger, but in reality it is non-harming.
The ancient masters say:
Joy is the feeling of joy.
Why does the feeling of joy arise in the contemplator at that time?
If it is the same as loving-kindness in bringing happiness, then it should be the same as compassion in removing suffering.
Moreover, a scripture says:
Because of delight, joy arises.
Joy is the feeling of joy, as has already been explained.
The mode of activity of this joy is the same as that delight. Because of joy, joy arises. What is the difference in meaning?
If it is said that there is a difference in meaning of lower and higher, then the meaning of serenity and happiness should also be so, because the reason for the distinction cannot be found.
Moreover, it contradicts the Abhidharma treatise, which says:
What is called joy?
It is the feeling, conceptualization, volition, consciousness, etc., associated with joy.
The meaning here is that the dharmas associated with joy are called joy because joy is predominant.
It is definitely not the case that feeling is associated with feeling.
If joy is the feeling of joy, why is it said to be associated with feeling?
If it is said that the Abhidharma is authoritative, then the original text of the Abhidharma should be recited without error.

This is also not so. In a treatise that takes principle as authoritative, the text must be determined on the basis of the scriptures. If it contradicts the scriptures, the principle is necessarily destroyed. One should not arbitrarily change the text of the treatise at will.
Therefore, this joy is definitely not the feeling of joy, but has delight as its nature or is simply non-greed.
That is to say, there is a separate greed that is a mental factor of evil. It thinks with regard to sentient beings:
How can I make it so that all the pleasures they obtain belong to me?
Joy is able to counteract that, and therefore it is non-greed. Because it necessarily occurs together with the faculty of joy.

The three stages can be obtained, like regret and sorrow together. Joy also has the clear characteristic of being free from craving. One does not greedily cling to the prosperity of others, and upon knowing that others have obtained [prosperity], one deeply rejoices. The antidote to mental heat is called joy. Therefore, one should know that this joy is also free from craving.

The essence of the immeasurable of equanimity is only free from craving. The difference between this and the third [immeasurable] is that one is free from thoughts of love and hatred, and so forth, and equally takes sentient beings as objects.
Like when one first enters a forest and gives rise to the perception of trees, the cause of impartial practice is called equanimity.
If the immeasurable of equanimity can also counteract anger, how is it different from free from anger?
Moreover, it is accepted that this equanimity directly counteracts desire and craving. How is it different from the contemplation of impurity?
First, the difference between equanimity and free from anger is that free from anger can counteract anger induced by hatred, and has the essence of being free from anger.
Equanimity can counteract anger induced by craving, and has the essence of being free from craving.
Isn't it also the case that, like equanimity, which has the nature of being free from craving, it can also counteract anger induced by craving?
Thus, if you admit that loving-kindness has nonhatred as its nature, then it should also be able to cure craving induced by hatred.
This objection is not reasonable, because the modes of activity of the two are opposed.

That is, the mode of activity of equanimity is opposed to both craving and hatred, because it is indifferent to the distinction of dear ones and enemies, and because neither love nor hatred arises from it.
For this reason, equanimity is only noncraving, because it directly cures craving and also cures hatred.
The mode of activity of loving-kindness is opposed to hatred, not to craving, because it evolves with the wish to bestow happiness on sentient beings.

Consequently, although loving-kindness and equanimity are both opposed to hatred, loving-kindness favors craving, while equanimity is able to oppose and harm it. Therefore, there is a great difference between these two.
Or, in the cultivation of equanimity, one cures hatred that is not directed toward a real object, while loving-kindness cures hatred that is directed toward a real object. Thus there is a difference.
Impure states and equanimity cure sexual craving and other craving, respectively, and for this reason there is a difference.
These four immeasurables do not harm or benefit others. Why then are they only good and not indeterminate?

Because they are able to directly counteract greed and anger, etc., because the characteristics of the loved and the unloved cannot attract them, and because they are able to cause the mind to turn freely.
The essence and characteristics of loving-kindness, etc., have been discussed in brief.

The specific characteristics of this resolve are as follows: To view sentient beings as oneself is called loving-kindness. To wish for sentient beings to be free from suffering is called compassion. To rejoice in others' prosperity is called sympathetic joy. To be indifferent to friends and enemies is called equanimity.

Moreover, not observing whether others have benefited or harmed, to view all equally as friends is called loving-kindness. To have pity on those who suffer is called compassion. By the power of resolve, to imagine that sentient beings obtain benefits and are free from harm and to rejoice is called sympathetic joy. To view the characteristics of sentient beings equally is called equanimity.
What are the differences in the four aspects? How can we cause sentient beings to obtain such happiness?
Thinking in this way, one enters the concentration of loving-kindness.
How can we cause sentient beings to be free from such suffering?
Thinking in this way, one enters the concentration of compassion.
Is it not delightful that all sentient beings obtain happiness and are free from suffering?
Thinking in this way, one enters the concentration of joy.
All sentient beings are equal and impartial, without any distinction of friend or foe. Thinking in this way, one enters the concentration of equanimity.
If such wishes are never fulfilled, are they not in vain?
The power of cultivating concentration can subdue anger and other afflictions. How can it be said to be in vain?
Shouldn't it be mistaken? How can it subdue delusions?
Wishing for happiness and so forth, how can it be mistaken?

This does not say that one has already obtained happiness and so forth, but only by superior understanding wishes that all sentient beings will obtain happiness and so forth, and is able to subdue all delusions. Therefore, cultivating these four is not in vain.
In the Concentration Scripture, four aspects are mentioned. How are they the same as the above?
They are all as explained above.

As for saying thinking in this way, one enters such-and-such concentration, if this statement is based on the immediately preceding condition, then loving-kindness and so forth should not have the principle of immediate succession, because they are aroused by separate thoughts.
If it were innate, this would contradict the scriptures.
In the stage of initial practice, it is induced by special added effort, but when it is perfected, it is also innate. The Concentration Scripture speaks of the initial stage without error.
What happiness does the initial thought of loving embrace wish for sentient beings?
Some say it wishes for the happiness of the third trance state, because this is the best of all happy feelings.
If one has not yet realized it oneself, one knows it through hearing.
Some say it wishes for the wonderful happiness of nirvana, because this is the best of all happinesses.
Some say it wishes for the happiness of arhats, because they are liberated from all passions.

When one is a beginner in practice, one has not yet realized this happiness, and because it is not yet realized, one cannot extend oneâ€™s mind to others. One only wishes for oneself and others to realize the happiness that one has realized and that others have realized and that is presently knowable. Therefore one only wishes for the present, the impure happiness born of correct principles, and wishes that others may experience it.

A verse says:

Moreover, for one who abides in detachment and diligently cultivates goodness, there is definitely good attainment that constantly flows like the vast ocean filled with water, and joy, lightness, and bliss are produced from this.

With a mind of non-stinginess, one takes such bliss as an object and wishes that all sentient beings may experience it together. The superior bliss of the superior trainees and the non-trainees is received.
How can one observe the inferior and bestow it upon others, without attracting an inferior result in the future?

If one says that one does not wish to give this to the superior, then one contradicts the universal object of sentient beings. It is only due to non-stinginess that merit benefits the basis, but it really cannot cause others to obtain bliss.

It is like a poor person who invites a rich person to share his own coarse and inferior resources. Although the rich person does not seek this favor, the giver is not at fault, because he expresses his own respectful heart and has nothing to begrudge.
This is also like that, so there is no fault.
It is like planting a small seed in good fields, and later the fruit obtained is much and also large, like half a seed of a gourd or a bottle gourd.
Therefore, it is not that by observing the inferior and bestowing it on others, one will then attract an inferior fruit in the future.
All take sentient beings of the desire realm as objects, because they can eliminate the hindrances such as hatred that take them as objects.

That is to say, in the desire realm there are three groups of sentient beings, enemies, friends, and those in between, who can give rise to hatred, etc. Among them, there is equanimity towards enemies and friends, etc., and one can then subdue the afflictions such as hatred.
Therefore, these objects are only sentient beings of the desire realm, and they definitely cannot take the form and formless realms as objects.
The essence of great compassion is the wholesome root of non-delusion, because by its power it can universally take the three realms as objects.
If the four immeasurables have only sentient beings as objects, why does a scripture say that one thinks of one direction, etc.?
This is because one extends the mind in a direction and thinks of all sentient beings there.

This is like the arising of the thought of disgust in the realm of desire, and therefore it is said that it is associated with the three lower stages of trance. This thought of resolve does not conform to the arising of joy. How can it be said to be similar to that?

The thought of resolve should be the same as that. However, it is extremely similar to joy, because it is able to attract the arising of true thought.
Doubt is not like this, because it is extremely contrary to truth.

This thought of resolve should be contrary to joy, because it has a different mode of activity, that is, a mode of activity that is neither joyful nor sorrowful.
Since compassion has a mode of activity that is sorrowful, it should not be associated with joy and pleasure, because the two modes of activity do not occur simultaneously.
If this is so, then it should not be admitted that it is associated with the feeling of indifference, because the feeling of indifference has a mode of activity that is neither joyful nor sorrowful.
Since it is not denied that it is associated with the feeling of indifference, it must certainly be associated with joy and pleasure, because it must not be totally unassociated with feeling.

Although it is said that these four are able to cure hatred, etc., they are not able to eliminate the passions, because they are born associated with the superior resolve of attention, and only true attention can eliminate the passions.
Also, they only have sentient beings as objects, and the elimination of the passions requires that one have as an object the principle of dharmas.
Also, they only have present objects, and the elimination of the passions requires that one have as an object the three times or the nontemporal.

When one first wishes to arouse the four immeasurables, one first divides sentient beings into three categories, namely, friends, neutral persons, and enemies, and each of the three is divided into three, namely, superior, middling, and inferior.
The superior friend is one from whom one has received great kindness in giving rise to the Dharma body, and it is difficult to live without abandoning him.
The middling friend is one with whom one has exchanged both wealth and the Dharma and who is extremely intimate.
The inferior friend is one with whom one has only exchanged wealth and who is also intimate.

The superior enemy is one who has taken away one's fame, merit, life, and friends.
The middling enemy is one who has taken away the conditions for one's own life and resources.
The inferior enemy is one who has taken away the conditions for one's friends' lives and resources.
Having divided sentient beings into these categories, the beginner in cultivating loving-kindness first arouses pure thoughts of giving happiness towards the superior friend.
If one's mind is hardened by evil intentions formed through beginningless habituation, and one bears deep resentment upon encountering slight harm, one should stop on account of this.

You should also encourage yourself to think of their great kindness, and you should again arouse the will to bring happiness to them. Through the power of repeated practice, resentment will be forever eliminated.

The will to bring happiness to others will continue without interruption. Once this has been accomplished, you should gradually extend this will to those who are neutral and to enemies, both those you are familiar with and those you are not.

Once you have achieved an attitude of equality toward the three groups of relatives, you should then extend this will to bring happiness to those who are neutral, to those of middling enmity, and to those of intense enmity, and you should gradually extend this will to bring happiness to all sentient beings, until finally you achieve an attitude of equality toward your worst enemies and your best friends, without any discrimination. At this point, you have perfected the practice of loving-kindness.
The practices of compassion and sympathetic joy should be explained in the same way.
